docs.lead_paragraph: In the two years since the revolutionary drug Viagra reached the market, the medical condition known as erectile dysfunction has gone from something that was the seldom mentioned cause of hidden misery and embarrassment to the basis of a billion-dollar-plus industry. Last week, an advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration recommended that a second oral drug, called Uprima, join Viagra on the market to help men get and maintain erections. And at least a dozen additional drugs to treat male or female sexual performance problems are being developed by other companies.

headline.main: Impotence Is Given Another Name, and a Drug Market Grows

docs.abstract: Erectile dysfunction has gone from something that was seldom mentioned to the basis of a billion-dollar-plus business in the two years since the drug Viagra reached market; advisory committee to FDA now recommends that second oral drug, called Uprima, join Viagra in the market; at least dozen additional drugs to treat male or female sexual performance problems are being developed by other companies; medical experts discuss role of social changes in emergence of new drugs; photo of Viagra pills; photo of Dr Ragab El-Rashidy, who discovered Uprima (L)
docs.snippet: In the two years since the revolutionary drug Viagra reached the market, the medical condition known as erectile dysfunction has gone from something that was the seldom mentioned cause of hidden misery and embarrassment to the basis of a...

docs.lead_paragraph: THE census takers haven't even gone home yet, and already James W. Hughes is writing about what they will find. As the megabytes from the census bureau spill in next year, he will write again. And again. ''I'll be in my demographic sandbox,'' he said. From his desk at Rutgers, Mr. Hughes will draw the outlines, as he has for a quarter-century, of the state's state of being: where the people live and what they live in, where the jobs are and where the money goes. But while Mr. Hughes is much cited as the man mostly likely to know what 8.2 million New Jerseyans are doing, he is not working on this by himself. As dean of the university's Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy, he presides over a knowledge factory for the state, or at least for the policy wonks within.

headline.main: Bloustein Makes, Policymakers Take; Those Who Make Decisions Affecting Public Life in the State Rely on the Institute at Rutgers and Its Well-Known Dean

docs.abstract: Article on work of Edward Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers; dean James W Hughes presides over New Jersey 'knowledge factory' that provides important research data for state agencies, planners and legislators; Hughes and others in field explain how raw data from census and other sources are analyzed and used in decision-making that affects life all around state; photos (M)
